contextId.occurrenceNote: The two occurrences of "everyone" are exaggerations, used to emphasize that this is true of very many people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: Everyone says ... everyone speaks

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to express that other things are much more important to God. Alternate translation: "Sacrifices and other offerings are not the things that delight you most" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: You have no delight in sacrifice or offering

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to show that these things were not the most important to God. Alternate translation: "animals burned on the altar and other offerings for our sins are not what you require most" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: you have not required burnt offerings or sin offerings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration. His enemies are not saying this constantly; they are saying it often. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: my enemies are always saying to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration; his enemies are not saying this constantly but are saying it often. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: they always say to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "all day long" is an exaggeration to emphasize that their people are being killed frequently. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "we are always in danger of people killing us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: we are being killed all day long

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is an exaggeration that emphasizes that the king is better looking than anyone else. The phrase "children of mankind" is an idiom and refers to all humans. Alternate translation: "You are more handsome than any other man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-idiom]])
contextId.glQuote: You are fairer than the children of mankind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "in all the earth" is an exaggeration to emphasize that they will rule over many nations. Alternate translation: "you will make rulers over many nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: you will make princes in all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "on a thousand hills" does not represent the total number of cattle that God owns. The number is an exaggeration that emphasizes that God owns all of the cattle in the world. The verb may be supplied from the previous phrase. Alternate translation: "all the cattle in the world are mine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: the cattle on a thousand hills

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggeration expresses that the man is in the temple very frequently to worship Yahweh. Alternate translation: "worship often in your courts" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: live in your courts

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to express how many enemies the writer has. Alternate translation: "more than I can count, like the hairs on my head" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: more than the hairs on my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggeration emphasizes that it is important to praise God often. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: always say

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggeration refers to everyone the writer can speak to. Alternate translation: "so as many people as I can tell will know" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: everyone who is to come

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration to emphasize that the lightning lit up everything the writer could see. Alternate translation: "lightning lit up everything as far as you could see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: lightning lit up the world

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is probably hyperbole. Alternate translation: "more water than they could possibly drink" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: enough to fill the depths of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: No one can count the grains of sand. There were more birds than anyone could count, but this is an exaggeration: there were probably not literally the same number of birds as grains of sand. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: as numerous as the sands of the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration. David cries out continually, but not literally at all times from dawn to dusk. Alternate translation: "continually" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: all day long

contextId.occurrenceNote: This exaggeration speaks about God punishing the writer as if God has completely destroyed the writer. Alternate translation: "the terrifying things you do have destroyed me" or "the terrifying things you do have almost destroyed me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: your terrifying deeds have annihilated me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angels will protect not only the reader's foot but the rest of his body as well. The words "not ... hit your foot on a stone" is an exaggerated metonym to say that not even small bad things will happen. This should probably not be taken as a promise that no bad things will ever happen again. Alternate translation: "you will not even hit your foot on a stone" or "not even the smallest bad thing will happen to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: you will not hit your foot on a stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "touch" means to harm, it's an exaggeration Yahweh used to strengthen his warning to not harm his people. Alternate translation: "Do not harm the people I have anointed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not touch my anointed ones

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes the ships rising and falling with the waves. The extremes of rising to the sky and falling to the depths are an exaggeration to express how horrible the windstorm was and how large the waves were. Alternate translation: "their ships would rise very high on the waves and then they would fall very low between the waves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: They reached up to the sky; they went down to the depths

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author uses exaggeration to explain that wherever he is, God is there too. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: If I fly away on the wings of the morning and go to live in the uttermost parts across the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: This hyperbole means that the writer would be unable to count God's thoughts. Alternate translation: "there would be more than I could count" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: they would be more in number than the sand

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an exaggeration that calls on all people who are alive to praise God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: everything that has breath
